title: Melba Flats
text:
Melba Flats is a railway siding on the <a href="Melba%20Line%2C%20Tasmania">Emu Bay Railway</a> east of <a href="Zeehan%2C%20Tasmania">Zeehan</a> that served as a terminus for trains carrying <a href="copper">copper</a> ore from the <a href="Mount%20Lyell%20Mining%20and%20Railway%20Company">Mount Lyell Mining and Railway Company</a> in <a href="West%20Coast%2C%20Tasmania">west coast</a> <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, once the Emu Bay Railway ceased services into the Zeehan townsite.
The section of line near Melba Flats was operational by December 1900. 
The Rosebery to Zeehan connection closed on the 14 August 1965, however the Rosebery to Melba Flats section re-opened on the 15 January 1970.
The Mount Lyell company had trucks deliver the ore along the Queenstown to Zeehan road to this siding, until 1994.
The Melba Flats area is the site of numerous historical workings; hand workings and hand constructed mining shafts dating back to the 1880s. <a href="Lead">Lead</a>, <a href="zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="silver">silver</a>, <a href="tin">tin</a> and <a href="nickel">nickel</a> have been located in varying quantities in the area.
<a href="Allegiance%20Mining">Allegiance Mining</a> in the 2000s investigated open pit mining of <a href="niccolite">niccolite</a> and <a href="pentlandite">pentlandite</a>, copper, gold and platinum minerals from small deposits on Melba Flats.
